title: 112_hr2898
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Regulation Moratorium and Jobs Preservation Act of 2011". It includes definitions for various terms used in the Act. The Act, known as the "Regulation Moratorium and Jobs Preservation Act of 2011," defines key terms such as "agency," "regulatory action," and "significant regulatory action." The "Regulation Moratorium and Jobs Preservation Act of 2011" defines key terms and criteria for regulatory actions, including impacts on small entities, other agencies' actions, budgetary effects, and legal or policy issues. The term "small entities" is defined in accordance with section 601(6) of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 3. SIGNIFICANT REGULATORY ACTIONS. No agency can take significant regulatory action until the unemployment rate is 7.7 percent or lower. The Secretary of Labor must report to the Director of the Office of Management and Budget when this threshold is met.

SEC. 4. WAIVERS. The President can waive section 3 for significant regulatory actions based on national security or emergency, with notification to Congress. The President can also request waivers from Congress, providing reasons for the waiver and identifying the regulatory action. Congress must act promptly on these requests. Congress must promptly consider and legislate on any waiver requests submitted under this subsection. SEC. 5. JUDICIAL REVIEW. In this section, a small business is defined as having less than 500 employees or a net worth under $7,000,000. Any person affected by regulatory violations can seek judicial review. Courts with jurisdiction over regulatory actions must also review claims under this Act. Courts can order agencies to take corrective action in line with this Act and relevant laws. The court can order corrective action for regulatory violations, award attorney fees to prevailing small businesses, and limit the commencement of civil actions. Limitation on commencing civil action: A person may seek judicial review within 1 year of the agency action or within 90 days after an enforcement action. If another law requires a civil action within a shorter period, that period applies.
